For those kind of limitations the constitution might need to be changed. In case a ordinary law states absolute limits it would be quite likely that the constitutional court challenge the law (either because it's a substantial contradiction to the universal character of the right to ask for asylum or as a challenge of Article 1 since the asylum seekers would be objectified as pure number). In other words: There is a good chance that such kind of law is going to be declared as invalid by the constitutional court. It wouldn't make sense to try to pass such a law since it would provoke an open fight within the conservative party and the social democrats, especially since there is a good chance that this law won't exist for too long. In order to make such kind of "threshold" sustainable, it needs to be implemented in the constitution (and even that might not be possible). However, there is simply no two third majority in the two chambers of the parliament (neither in Bundestag nor in Bundesrat) to do so.

I have been following the refugee issue for some time, but not too closely. It seemed interestingly different than others questions I tackled. As ever we start by asking about a BASE RATE. What would be a base rate here? Arguably all instances of massive migration in Europe happened sufficiently far in the past, and under sufficiently different circumstances, that they would be poor guides now. I was a bit lost, reading random articles about refugees, when I came upon stats [1, chart #5] on the number of asylum requests *as a fraction of the population* in 2015. I had heard that Hungary now outright rejects refugees, and that recently Austria put a cap on its number of refugees. Lo and behold, they are both near the top of the chart: Hungary had 18 asylum applications per 1000 inhabitants, and Austria had 10.2. According to this theory, Sweden, which is second on that chart with 16.7, should have taken action to curb the number of refugees coming in. It hasn't put a cap on the number [2] but it's taken other measures [3]. To test the theory a different way, I tried to see whether the Netherlands (near the bottom of the chart, with 2.7) had announced any refugee-controlling measure, and I couldn't find any news of it. So maybe there's something to the theory that a big determinant of whether a country acts to limit refugee numbers is something like "number of refugees accepted"/population, for which [1, chart #5] is a proxy. It also seems logically plausible; I feel I could tell a story about why it should be so. Germany currently sits at 5.9 asylum requests per 1000 inhabitants. Since Germany & Austria are neighbors and similar in many ways, I will assume for a base rate that Germany would do as Austria [4] and announce a cap one month after the number of asylum requests per capita reaches 10.2 / 1000. That means it needs to receive  ((10.2 - 5.9)/1000)*(German pop) = (4.3/1000)*(80 million) = 43*8000 = 344k asylum applications before 1 June 2016. It received 181k in Q1 2016, up from Q1 2015 [5]. If this keeps up for 2 more months, they would hit (181k)*5/3 = 302k on 1 June 2016, about 12% short. In order to get to the target 344k, the rate of requests would have to go up 35% in April-May. I don't see why it should but I'm not very certain, so I assign it a low-ish probability of 10-20%, say 15%. To adjust this, I can think of two questions: (1) could something happen to make Germany cap with more/fewer refugees per capita than Austria? (2) Is there any reason why the announcement might be made in more/less than a month after the critical number is reached? The big obvious thing for (1) is an Islamic terrorist attack. But Germany has essentially no history of Islamic terrorism [6]. On the other side, German culture seems to broadly support this receptiveness, and have features that dampen a reaction against refugees [7]. This is fuzzy but it makes me want to knock off a few %, call it 10% now. On (2), Merkel has made a very big deal of being pro-refugee, and very recently has outright rejected a proposal to cap their number [8]. My guess is she would postpone such a cap as long as she can. Another downgrade, to 5%. Now to read what everyone else has said! [1] http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34131911

EU and Turkey new deal:
Key points from the agreement
Returns: All "irregular migrants" crossing from Turkey into Greece from 20 March will be sent back. Each arrival will be individually assessed by the Greek authorities.
One-for-one: For each migrant returned to Turkey, a Syrian migrant will be resettled in the EU. Priority will be given to those who have not tried to illegally enter the EU and the number is capped at 72,000.
Visa restrictions: Turkish nationals should have access to the Schengen passport-free zone by June. This will not apply to non-Schengen countries like Britain.
Financial aid: The EU is to speed up the allocation of €3 bn ($3.3 bn; £2.3 bn) in aid to Turkey to help migrants.
Turkey EU membership: Both sides agreed to "re-energise" Turkey's bid to join the European bloc, with talks due by July.

This decision will be shaped by (as well as shape) the Federal Diet elections in Germany.  The migrant, refugee & asylee crisis will either constrain or expand opportunities for the likelihood of a limitation policy in some form.  It also simultaneously will influence the Federal Diet elections (for the date has not been confirmed).  It is anticipated that elections will occur 2017.  German law requires that the next election should take place on a Sunday between 46-48 months after the assembly's first sitting. Since the current Bundestag first sat on 22 October 2013, the latest date for the next election is 22 October 2017 (a Sunday). The earliest date is 27 August 2017, the first Sunday after 22 August.   Elections to the Bundestag (Parliament) can occur earlier if a motion of no confidence in the Chancellor is passed by the current parliament.  There is no doubt that the current political dynamic around the migrant (largely defined) crisis in the EU will be shaped (along with what happens in Germany) by the dynamics of border closings in Greece and the Balkan states (along with migrant/refugee limits in these frontline states)

(no change) One of the reasons I think this will not happen very soon is the constitutional issue. OTOH 1. In the US amending the constitution is almost impossible; in most other democracies I know of, they have a much different approach. In Germany (quoted from wikipedia) "Amendments[edit]
Process[edit]
Article 79 states the Basic Law may be amended by an absolute two-thirds majority of the Bundestag along with a simple two-thirds majority of the Bundesrat, excluding amendment of those areas defined by the eternity clause.[15] History[edit]
The Basic Law has been amended 50 times as of 2003.[16] Important changes to the Basic Law were the re-introduction of conscription and the establishment of the Bundeswehr in 1956. Therefore, several articles were introduced into the constitution, e.g., Art. 12a, 17, 45a-c, 65a, 87a-c GG. Another important reform were the introduction in 1968 of emergency competences, for example Art. 115 Paragraph 1 GG. This was done by a grand coalition of the two main political parties CDU/CSU and SPD and was accompanied by heated debate. In the following year there were changes to the articles regarding the distribution of taxes between federal government and the states of Germany. During reunification, the two states discussed the possibility of drafting a new common constitution followed by a plebiscite, as envisioned in Art. 146 (1990), but this path was ultimately not taken. Instead the Federal Republic of Germany and the German Democratic Republic decided to keep the Basic Law with only minor changes, because it had proved to be effective in West Germany. To facilitate reunification and to reassure other states, the FRG made some changes to the Basic Law. Article 23 was fulfilled by reunification itself, and then withdrawn to indicate that there were no other parts of Germany that existed outside of the unified territory.[17][18] The question of “using″ Article 146 to draw a new constitution, and hold a referendum, was left to the twelfth (and first all-German) Bundestag, who after considering the question decided against a new draft. However, the Bundestag passed the constitutional reform of 1994, a minor change, but still fulfilling the constitutional question together with some other amendments between 1990 and 1994. For example, affirmative action was allowed in women's rights, and environmental protection was made a policy objective of the state in the new Article 20a. In 1992, membership in the European Union was institutionalised (Art. 23 GG). For the privatisation of the railways and the postal service, amendments were necessary as well. Since then, there have only been minor amendments, with the exception of the Balanced Budget Amendment added in 2009, which becomes fully effective in 2016. In 2002, protection of animals was explicitly mentioned in Art. 20a GG. The most controversial debate arose concerning the limitation of the right to asylum in 1993 as in the current version of Art. 16 a GG. This change was later challenged and confirmed in a judgment by the constitutional court. Another controversy was spawned by the limitation of the right to the invulnerability of the private domain (Unverletzlichkeit der Wohnung) by means of acoustic observation (Großer Lauschangriff). This was done by changes to Art. 13 Paragraph 3 and Art. 6 GG. The changes were challenged in the constitutional court, but the judges confirmed the changes. Other changes took place regarding a redistribution of competencies between federal government and the Länder." So my impression is that when something is important enough, there are changes and the process does not need to be lengthy. 2. The other way to significantly limit rights related to asylum are legal shenanigans (esoteric legal term related to redefining, re-interpreting, etc.).

The problem with this question is what "announce that it is limiting the number" means. Germany is, of course, going to limit the number of refugees sometime this year. Of course. But is Germany going to "announce" this? I can't see how.  After all, the NUMBER of refugees is not really important compared to several principles. And one of the principles has to be a clearer definition of the word "refugee." Once that is defined satisfactorily, Germany will announce that it is open to as many (properly defined) refugees as can make it to Germany. Sadly, those who do not meet the definition are not welcome. The subsequent refusal of entry and/or deportation of the significant percentage of migrants who will not match the definition will be a clearer "announcement." And this will be an extremely reasonable correction to the greeting-card-sentiment-based policy that has heretofore prevailed.

On KNOW-WHY.NET you will find this (https://www.know-why.net/model/CVOcWNOeuzvXDWTQboi_O8Q) and other refugee models that argue that we should have no limit for sheltering refugees but a reasonable limit to integrate refugees. However, right now media is escalating right wing tendencies throughout Europe, thus a quick shot from politics is not unlikely.

Once again, I find myself wondering what is meant by a question. This is frustrating. I've been interpreting this question to mean that ANY action which in any way limits the total number--regardless of if it is stated as a direct effort to do so or if it just has the consequence of making some ineligible--would satisfy this question. This is a fairly broad interpretation of the question.  It seems, however, that other forecasters are interpreting the question more narrowly--to require that there be a statement by Germany along the lines that "the number will be capped/limited/restricted" or "a quota will be imposed". Consequently, I've asked for a clarification:  will this question be resolved positively based on a broad interpretation or a narrow one?

Putting a fixed cap would be a devastating blow to Merkel's stance and Germany's leadership on the migration issue. Certainly, Germany will be implementing measures to slow the flow, but can hardly envision such an announcement.

This is my opening forecast and indeed my first GJP forecast ever so I plan to make many, perhaps daily adjustments to this judgement.  For now I think one of the most relevant factors is the timing of the local, state and national elections.  According to this site: http://www.wahlrecht.de/termine.htm the next national elections do not occur until Fall of 2017.  There are local elections and state elections in the meantime but I am unclear how much influence they will have on national politics.  Clearly I am assuming that Merkel's position is central to any actual change.  I need to investigate her relationship to her party and her coalition  partners in order to better predict what may move her.  In general she is someone who is careful and empirical in her judgements.  She also brings to this issue several kinds of legitimacy which matter in a German leader:  she has a PhD in physics, she was born in the West but raised in the East after her father who was a Lutheran pastor accepted a position in the DDR.  These biographical details matter, I think, because she has both an ethical and empirical manner in her approach to politics which I think is strongly influencing her approach to the matter of refugees and asylum seekers.  Her decision to radically welcome Syrians and others surprised me given how unyielding she had been in the negotiations with the Greeks.  I suspect she may now wish she had been more reserved in her judgement but nonetheless, I expect that she will expend considerable social and political capital to avoid utterly retracting her position.  While there are factors that could push her and her partners to make some changes in the next six months (I need to do a great deal more reading on this before I can calculate probable behavior) the counterweight will be the relationship Germany has with Turkey, concerns about the rising number of casualties in the Syrian war and international attention which is not flagging.  I'm also relatively certain that she will not respond to pressure from the far right.  Indeed the more the far right protests, especially in places that were once the DDR, the more I would expect her to resist calls to limit the total number of refugees Germany will accept.  I do expect that there will be more changes about the types of refugees or the locations from whence they may come but that has already happened.  I look forward to reading comments from others on this topic.

I'm expecting some sort of quota system that allows a humanitarian waiver. ANTICIPATED RESOLUTION CHALLENGE There is a great difference between a nominal notion (in name only) and practical reality. Suppose Merkel announces a quota system designed to allow 500,000 immigrants per year, but simultaneously announces that the Bundestag may waive the quota in any year for humanitarian purposes, and does so. Was this an announcement of a limitation? Yes nominally, no practically. Or, perhaps more likely, what if there is no reference to absolute numbers, but only green-eyed, three fingered people over seven feet tall are allowed in? Would such an announcement be of a limitation? No nominally, yes practically. In all cases, reality is not in the name.
